Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in determining that Ms. Ryan met the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Ryan was absent for 1,136 days during the four-year period preceding her application, resulting in only 324 days of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship Judge initially approved application; Federal Court overturned the decision
Remedy_Requested: Minister appealed the Citizenship Judge's decision seeking to set aside the approval
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was unreasonable and fell outside acceptable outcomes
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada due to illness and personal reasons
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory 1,095-day physical residence requirement
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence, qualitative assessment of ties to Canada, illness-related absences
Procedural_Issue: Appeal by the Minister to the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of illness, ties to Canada
Application_Basis: Accumulation of 1,095 days of residence within four years before application
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and reasons for absences, connection to Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge’s decision
Governing_Rule: Residence requires physical presence with limited exceptions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence to meet statutory threshold
Harm_Assessment: Undermining integrity of statutory residency requirements for citizenship
Cause_Description: Ms. Ryan's citizenship approval despite significant absence from Canada due to illness and personal reasons
Evidence_Handling: Considered but found insufficient to justify deviation from physical presence requirement
Evidence_Issues: Weight given to non-physical presence factors such as ties to Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not met – only 324 days present out of required 1,095
Evidence_Assessment: Qualitative test applied by Citizenship Judge deemed inappropriate
Decision_Rationale: Statutory requirement is primarily quantitative; qualitative considerations cannot override clear absence of physical presence
Evidentiary_Issues: Use of qualitative factors to compensate for lack of physical presence
